paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Analyzing Data with DataFrame Queries
**Objective:** Analyze account data and mobile device data using DataFrame queries
**File locations:**
- Data files (local): 
    - /home/devuser/data/telco/accountdevice
    - /home/devuser/data/telco/base_stations.parquet
- Data files (HDFS): /user/zeppelin/devices.json
- Hive Tables: telco.accounts

**Successful outcome:** 
**Before you begin:** 
**Related lessons:** 

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Analyzing Data with DataFrame Queries
Objective: Analyze account data and mobile device data using DataFrame queries
File locations:

  • Data files (local):
    • $DEVDATA/accountdevice
    • $DEVDATA/base_stations.parquet
  • Data files (HDFS): /devsh_loudacre/devices.json
  • Hive Tables: devsh.accounts

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons:

Setup

Important: This exercise depends on ***Insert previous exercise title here (with link?)*** . If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

$ $DEVSH/scripts/catchup.sh
Lab
Query DataFrames Using Column Expressions

paragraphs.title: 1 - Review the API documentation for the Spark Column class
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Review the API docs for the `Column` class (which is in the Python module `pyspark.sql`). Take note of the various options available.

msg.data:
Optional: Review the API docs for the Column class (which is in the Python module
pyspark.sql and the Scala package org.apache.spark.sql). Take note of
the various options available.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a new DataFrame called accountsDF
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame called `accountsDF` based on the Hive `telco.accounts` table.

msg.data: Create a new DataFrame called accountsDF based on the Hive devsh.accounts table.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Practice using both column reference syntaxes
paragraphs.text:
%md
Try a simple query with `select`, using both column reference syntaxes.

msg.data: Try a simple query with select, using both column reference syntaxes.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a column object
paragraphs.text:
%md
To explore column expressions, create a column object to work with, based on the `first_name` column in the `accountsDF` DataFrame.

msg.data:
To explore column expressions, create a column object to work with, based on the
first_name column in the accountsDF DataFrame.

paragraphs.title: 5 - View available methods and attributes of the Column class
paragraphs.text:
%md
Note that the object type is `Column`. To see available methods and attributes, use tab completion--that is, enter `fnCol`. followed by `TAB`.

msg.data:
Note that the object type is Column. To see available methods and attributes, use
tab completion–that is, enter fnCol. followed by TAB.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Use a column expression to create a new column object
paragraphs.text:
%md
New `Column` objects are created when you perform operations on existing columns. Create a new `Column` object based on a column expression that identifies users whose first name is Lucy using the equality operator on the `fnCol` object you created above.

msg.data:
New Column objects are created when you perform operations on existing
columns. Create a new Column object based on a column expression that identifies
users whose first name is Lucy using the equality operator on the fnCol object you
created above.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Use the lucyCol column expression in a select statement
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the `lucyCol` column expression in a `select` statement. Because `lucyCol` is based on a boolean expression, the column values will be `true` or `false` depending on the value of the `first_name` column. Confirm that users named Lucy are identified with the value `true`.

msg.data:
Use the lucyCol column expression in a select statement. Because lucyCol
is based on a boolean expression, the column values will be true or false
depending on the value of the first_name column. Confirm that users named
Lucy are identified with the value true.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Use the where operation
paragraphs.text:
%md
The `where` operation requires a boolean-based column expression. Use the `lucyCol` column expression in a where transformation and view the data in the resulting DataFrame. Confirm that only users named Lucy are in the data.

msg.data:
The where operation requires a boolean-based column expression. Use the
lucyCol column expression in a where transformation and view the data in the
resulting DataFrame. Confirm that only users named Lucy are in the data.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Try a query without assigning the result to a variable
paragraphs.text:
%md
Column expressions do not need to be assigned to a variable. Try the same query without using the `lucyCol` variable.

msg.data:
Column expressions do not need to be assigned to a variable. Try the same query
without using the lucyCol variable.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Column expressions can be used wherever a column could be used
paragraphs.text:
%md
Column expressions are not limited to where operations like those above. They can be used in any transformation for which a simple column could be used, such as a `select`. Try selecting the `city` and `state` columns, and the first three characters of the `phone_number` column (in the U.S., the first three digits of a phone number are known as the area code). Use the `substr` operator on the `phone_number` column to extract the area code.

msg.data:
Column expressions are not limited to where operations like those above. They can
be used in any transformation for which a simple column could be used, such as a
select. Try selecting the city and state columns, and the first three characters
of the phone_number column (in the U.S., the first three digits of a phone number
are known as the area code). Use the substr operator on the phone_number
column to extract the area code.

paragraphs.title: 11 - Use the alias operator to rename a column
paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice that in the last step, the values returned by the query were correct, but the column name was `substring(phone_number, 1, 3)`, which is long and hard to work with. Repeat the same query, using the alias operator to rename that column as `area_code`.

msg.data:
Notice that in the last step, the values returned by the query were correct, but the
column name was substring(phone_number, 1, 3), which is long and
hard to work with. Repeat the same query, using the alias operator to rename that
column as area_code.

paragraphs.title: 12 - Practice using transformations
paragraphs.text:
%md
Perform a query that results in a DataFrame with just `first_name` and `last_name` columns, and only includes users whose first and last names both begin with the same two letters. (For example, the user Roberta Roget would be included, because both her first and last names begin with"Ro".)

%md
### Group and Count Data by Name

msg.data: Group and Count Data by Name

paragraphs.title: 13 - Query the DataFrame using groupBy with the count aggregation transformation
paragraphs.text:
%md
Query the `accountsDF` DataFrame using `groupBy` with count to find out the total number people sharing each last name. (Note that the count aggregation transformation returns a DataFrame, unlike the `count` DataFrame action, which returns a single value to the driver.)

msg.data:
Query the accountsDF DataFrame using groupBy with count to find out the
total number people sharing each last name. (Note that the count aggregation
transformation returns a DataFrame, unlike the count DataFrame action, which
returns a single value to the driver.)

paragraphs.title: 14 - Use groupBy on multiple columns
paragraphs.text:
%md
You can also group by multiple columns. Query `accountsDF` again, this time counting the number of people who share the same last and first name.

msg.data:
You can also group by multiple columns. Query accountsDF again, this time
counting the number of people who share the same last and first name.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Join Account Data with Cellular Towers by Zip Code

msg.data: Join Account Data with Cellular Towers by Zip Code

paragraphs.title: 15 - Review the base_stations.parquet file
paragraphs.text:
%md
In this section, you will join the accounts data that you have been using with data about cell tower base station locations, which is in the `base_stations.parquet` file. Start by reviewing the schema and a few records of the data. Use the `parquet-tools` command in a separate terminal window (not the one running the Spark shell).

    $ parquet-tools schema /home/devuser/data/telco/base_stations.parquet
    $ parquet-tools head /home/devuser/data/telco/base_stations.parquet

msg.data:
In this section, you will join the accounts data that you have been using with data
about cell tower base station locations, which is in the base_stations.parquet
file. Start by reviewing the schema and a few records of the data. Use the
parquet-tools command in a separate terminal window (not the one running
the Spark shell).

$ parquet-tools schema $DEVDATA/base_stations.parquet
$ parquet-tools head $DEVDATA/base_stations.parquet

paragraphs.title: 16 - Upload the data file to HDFS

msg.data: $ hdfs dfs -put $DEVDATA/base_stations.parquet devsh_loudacre/

paragraphs.title: 17 - Create a new DataFrame using the base stations data
paragraphs.text:
%md
In your Spark shell, create a new DataFrame called `baseDF` using the base stations data. Review the `baseDF` schema and data to ensure it matches the data in the Parquet file.

msg.data:
In your Spark shell, create a new DataFrame called baseDF using the base stations
data. Review the baseDF schema and data to ensure it matches the data in the
Parquet file.

paragraphs.title: 18 - Perform a join on baseDF and accountsDF
paragraphs.text:
%md
Some account holders live in zip codes that have a base station. Join `baseDF` and `accountsDF` to find those users. For each of those users, include their account ID, first name, last name, and the ID and location data (latitude and longitude) for the base station in their zip code.

msg.data:
Some account holders live in zip codes that have a base station. Join baseDF and
accountsDF to find those users. For each of those users, include their account ID,
first name, last name, and the ID and location data (latitude and longitude) for the
base station in their zip code.
Count Active Devices

paragraphs.title: 19 - Review the account device data and upload it to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
The `accountdevice` CSV dataset contains a list of all the devices used by all accounts. Each row in the data set includes a row ID, an account ID, an ID for the type of device, the date the device was activated for the account, and the specific device ID.

The CSV data file is in the `/home/devuser/data/telco/accountdevice` directory. Review the data in the data set, then upload the directory and its contents to the HDFS directory `/user/zeppelin/accountdevice`.

msg.data:
The accountdevice CSV dataset contains a list of all the devices used by all
accounts. Each row in the data set includes a row ID, an account ID, an ID for the
type of device, the date the device was activated for the account, and the specific
device ID.

The CSV data file is in the $DEVDATA/accountdevice directory. Review the data
in the data set, then upload the directory and its contents to the HDFS directory
/devsh_loudacre/accountdevice.

paragraphs.title: 20 - Create a DataFrame based on the account device data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a DataFrame based on the `accountdevice` data files.

msg.data: Create a DataFrame based on the accountdevice data files.

paragraphs.title: 21 - Analyze the data presented in this exercise
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the account device data and the DataFrames you created previously in this exercise to find the total number of each device model across all *active* accounts -- that is, accounts that have not been closed. The new DataFrame should be sorted from most to least common model. Save the data as Parquet files in a directory called `/user/zeppelin/top_devices` with the following columns:

```
| Column Name | Description                                                                                  | Example Value  |
|-------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------|
| device_id   | The ID number of each known device (including those that might not be in use by any account) | 18             |
| make        | The manufacturer name for the device                                                         | Ronin          |
| model       | The model name for the device                                                                | Novelty Note 2 |
| active_num  | The total number of the model used by active accounts                                        | 2092           |
```

Hints:
- Active accounts are those with a null value for `acct_close_dt` (account close date) in the `accounts` table.
- The `account_id` column in the device accounts data corresponds to the `acct_num` column in `accounts` table.
- The `device_id` column in the device accounts data corresponds to the devnum column in the list of known devices in the `/devsh_loudacre/devices.json` file.
- When you count devices, use `withColumnRenamed` to rename the count column to `active_num`. (The `count` column name is ambiguous because it is both a function and a column.)
- The query to complete this exercise is somewhat complicated and includes a sequence of many transformations. You may wish to assign variables to the intermediate DataFrames resulting from the transformations that make up the query to make the code easier to work with and debug.

msg.data:
Use the account device data and the DataFrames you created previously in this exercise to find the total number of each device model across all active accounts – that is, accounts that have not been closed. The new DataFrame should be sorted from most to least common model. Save the data as Parquet files in a directory called /user/zeppelin/top_devices with the following columns:

| Column Name | Description                                                                                  | Example Value  |
|-------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------|
| device_id   | The ID number of each known device (including those that might not be in use by any account) | 18             |
| make        | The manufacturer name for the device                                                         | Ronin          |
| model       | The model name for the device                                                                | Novelty Note 2 |
| active_num  | The total number of the model used by active accounts                                        | 2092           |

Hints:

  • Active accounts are those with a null value for acct_close_dt (account close date) in the accounts table.
  • The account_id column in the device accounts data corresponds to the acct_num column in accounts table.
  • The device_id column in the device accounts data corresponds to the devnum column in the list of known devices in the /devsh_loudacre/devices.json file.
  • When you count devices, use withColumnRenamed to rename the count column to active_num. (The count column name is ambiguous because it is both a function and a column.)
  • The query to complete this exercise is somewhat complicated and includes a sequence of many transformations. You may wish to assign variables to the intermediate DataFrames resulting from the transformations that make up the query to make the code easier to work with and debug.

### Join Account Data with Cellular Towers by Zip Code

paragraphs.title: 15 - Review the base_stations.parquet file
16 - Upload the data file to HDFS

msg.data: Count Active Devices

paragraphs.title: 19 - Review the account device data and upload it to HDFS
20 - Create a DataFrame based on the account device data
21 - Analyze the data presented in this exercise
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Create a DataFrame with only active accounts
activeAccountsDF = accountsDF.where(accountsDF.acct_close_dt.isNull())

# Create a DataFrame with a device model IDs for only devices used by active accounts
activeAcctDevsDF =  activeAccountsDF.join(accountDeviceDF,activeAccountsDF.acct_num == accountDeviceDF.account_id).select("device_id")

# Sum up the total number of each device model 
sumDevicesDF = activeAcctDevsDF.groupBy("device_id").count().withColumnRenamed("count","active_num")

# Order by count in descending order
orderDevicesDF = sumDevicesDF.orderBy(sumDevicesDF.active_num.desc())

# Create a DataFrame based on the devices.json file
devDF = spark.read.json("/user/zeppelin/devices.json")

# Join the list of device model totals with the list of devices
# to get the make and model for each device
joinDevicesDF = orderDevicesDF.join(devDF,sumDevicesDF.device_id == devDF.devnum)

# Write out the data with the correct columns
# Use overwrite mode so solution can be run multiple times
joinDevicesDF.select("device_id","make","model",joinDevicesDF.active_num).write.mode("overwrite").save("/user/zeppelin/top_devices")
# *** ^^^Should be saved as parquet !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

paragraphs.title: Review the resulting file
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -get /user/zeppelin/top_devices /tmp/

# In a separate shell:
parquet-tools head /tmp/top_devices

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
